sen.j: 月山富田城の戦い（がっさんとだじょうのたたかい）とは1542年-1543年・1565年-1566年に尼子氏の本拠である出雲国の月山富田城（現；島根県安来市）を巡って発生した合戦である。
sen.e: The Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle was a battle that occurred from 1542 to 1543 and from 1565 to 1566 concerning the Gassan Toda-jo Castle located in the Izumo Province (present-day Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) which was the base of the Amago clan.

The Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle was a battle that occurred from 1542 to 1543 and from 1565 to 1566 over Gassan Toda-jo Castle located in Izumo Province (present-day Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) which was the base of the Amago clan.

The Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle was a battle that occurred from 1542 to 1543 and from 1565 to 1566 over Gassan Toda-jo Castle located in Izumo Province (present-day Yasugi City, Shimane Prefecture) which was the base of the Amago clan.

sen.j: この合戦は第一次月山富田城の戦いと第二次月山富田城の戦いに分けることができる。
sen.e: This battle consisted of two parts: the First Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle and the Second Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle.
This battle consisted of two parts: the First Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle and the Second Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle.
This battle consisted of two parts: the First Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle and the Second Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle.

sen.j: 第一次では大内氏と毛利氏の連合軍と尼子氏の戦いとなった。
sen.e: The first battle was a fight between the Ouchi and Mori allied forces and the Amago clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The first battle was a fight between the Ouchi and Mori allied forces and the Amago clan.
The first battle was a fight between the Ouchi and Mori allied forces and the Amago clan.

sen.j: 大内氏が滅亡した後の第二次では毛利元就がこの戦いを開始し、尼子氏を滅亡させた。
sen.e: After the fall of the Ouchi clan, Motonari MORI started the second battle and destroyed the Amago clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the fall of the Ouchi clan, Motonari MORI started the second battle and destroyed the Amago clan.
After the fall of the Ouchi clan, Motonari MORI started the second battle and destroyed the Amago clan.

tit.j: 第一次月山富田城の戦い
tit.e: The First Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle
The First Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle
The First Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle

sen.j: 天文 (元号)10年（1541年）、尼子晴久率いる尼子軍が毛利氏の本拠である吉田郡山城を30,000の兵で攻めたものの、毛利軍の3,000の兵と大内軍の援軍によって撃退された（吉田郡山城の戦いを参照）。
sen.e: In 1541, the Amago army under the command of Haruhisa AMAGO attacked the Yoshida Koriyama-jo Castle, the base of the Mori clan, with 30,000 men; however, it was repelled by the Mori army with 3,000 men and the reinforcement of the Ouchi clan (See: Seige of Koriyama)

In 1541, the Amago army under the command of Haruhisa AMAGO attacked Yoshida Koriyama-jo Castle, the base of the Mori clan, with 30,000 men; however, he was repelled by the 3,000 strong Mori army with reinforcements from the Ouchi clan (See Seige of Koriyama)

In 1541, the Amago army under the command of Haruhisa AMAGO attacked Yoshida Koriyama-jo Castle, the base of the Mori clan, with 30,000 men; however, he was repelled by the 3,000 strong Mori army with reinforcements from the Ouchi clan (See Siege of Koriyama)

sen.j: この尼子氏による安芸遠征の失敗後、尼子経久が死去し、天文11年1月11日（1542年1月26日）に出雲国に向かって大内・毛利両軍が出陣する。
sen.e: After the Amago clan failed in this invasion of the Aki Province, Tsunehisa AMAGO died; the Ouchi and Mori armies departed for the Izumo Province on February 5, 1542.
sen.cmt: 「１５４２年１月２６日」はユリウス暦なので、グレゴリオ暦に訂正しました
sen.e: Following Tsunehisa AMAGO's death after the Amago clan failed in the invasion of Aki Province, the Ouchi and Mori armies departed for Izumo Province on February 5, 1542.
Following Tsunehisa AMAGO's death after the Amago clan failed in the invasion of Aki Province, the Ouchi and Mori armies departed for Izumo Province on February 5, 1542.

sen.j: 大内軍は大内義隆自らが総大将となり、陶隆房、杉重矩、内藤興盛、弘中隆包ら15,000の兵を率いて出兵。
sen.e: For the Ouchi army, Yoshitaka Ouchi himself became a supreme commander and went into battle with an army of 15,000 men including Takafusa SUE, Shigenori SUGI, Okimori NAITO, and Takakane HIRONAKA.
For the Ouchi army, Yoshitaka Ouchi himself became supreme commander and went into battle with an army of 15,000 men including Takafusa SUE, Shigenori SUGI, Okimori NAITO, and Takakane HIRONAKA.
For the Ouchi army, Yoshitaka Ouchi himself became supreme commander and went into battle with an army of 15,000 men including Takafusa SUE, Shigenori SUGI, Okimori NAITO, and Takakane HIRONAKA.

sen.j: 毛利軍も毛利元就、小早川正平、益田藤兼ら安芸国・周防国・石見国の国人衆を集めて出雲へ赴いた。
sen.e: For the Mori army, Motonari MORI, Masahira KOBAYAKAWA, and Fujikane MASUDA departed for the Izumo Province recruiting local samurai of the Aki, Suo, and Iwami Prorinces.
For the Mori army, Motonari MORI, Masahira KOBAYAKAWA, and Fujikane MASUDA departed for Izumo Province recruiting local samurai from Aki, Suo, and Iwami Provinces.
For the Mori army, Motonari MORI, Masahira KOBAYAKAWA, and Fujikane MASUDA departed for Izumo Province recruiting local samurai from Aki, Suo, and Iwami Provinces.

sen.j: 4月に出雲に侵入したものの、赤穴城の攻略が3ヶ月と長くかかり、10月になって三刀屋峰に本陣を構えた。
sen.e: In April, they advanced into the Izumo Province; however, it took three long months to capture the Akana-jo Castle, so they set up their headquarters in Mitoyamine in October.
In April, they advanced into Izumo Province; however, as it took three long months to capture Akana-jo Castle they set up their headquarters in Mitoyamine in October.
In May, they advanced into Izumo Province; however, as it took three long months to capture Akana-jo Castle they set up their headquarters in Mitoyamine in November.

sen.j: その後、年を越して月山富田城を望む京羅木山に本陣を移す。
sen.e: Soon after greeting the New Year, they relocated their headquarters to Mt. Kyoragi, which overlooked the Gassan Toda-jo Castle.
Soon after the New Year they relocated their headquarters to Mount Kyoragi, which overlooked Gassan Toda-jo Castle.
Soon after the New Year they relocated their headquarters to Mount Kyoragi, which overlooked Gassan Toda-jo Castle.

sen.j: 3月になって攻防戦が開始され、戦端が開かれたが、糧道にて尼子軍のゲリラ戦術を受け兵站の補給に苦しんだ。
sen.e: In March, they started to fight back and forth, and the battle began; they encountered a guerrilla attack by the Amago army, and sufferred from the shortage of military supplies.
In March battle commenced, but they encountered guerrilla attacks from the Amago army and suffered from a shortage of military supplies.
In April battle commenced, but they encountered guerrilla attacks from the Amago army and suffered from a shortage of military supplies.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に訂正 March→April

sen.j: その上、大内軍に属していた三刀屋久扶、三沢為清、本城常光、吉川興経が尼子方につき大内方が劣勢になった。
sen.e: Furthermore, allies of the Ouchi army, such as Hisasuke MITOYA, Tamekiyo MISAWA, Tsunemitsu HONJO, and Okitsune KIKKAWA took the Amako's side, so the Ouchi's side became inferior in strength.
Furthermore, allies of the Ouchi army, such as Hisasuke MITOYA, Tamekiyo MISAWA, Tsunemitsu HONJO, and Okitsune KIKKAWA took Amago's side, so the Ouchi forces became inferior in strength.
Furthermore, allies of the Ouchi army, such as Hisasuke MITOYA, Tamekiyo MISAWA, Tsunemitsu HONJO, and Okitsune KIKKAWA took Amago's side, so the Ouchi forces became inferior in strength.

sen.j: 大内方は5月7日に撤退にとりかかり、5月25日に山口市に帰還した。
sen.e: The Ouchi's side began to withdraw on June 19, 1543, and returned to Yamaguchi City on July 7.
sen.cmt: 日付はグレゴリオ暦に訂正しました
sen.e: The Ouchi forces began to withdraw on June 19, 1543, and returned to Yamaguchi City on July 7.
The Ouchi forces began to withdraw on June 19, 1543, and returned to Yamaguchi City on July 7.

sen.j: この1年4ヶ月にも及ぶ遠征の挙句の敗戦の上、この遠征で養嗣子の大内晴持を失った義隆は以後政治に対する意欲を失ってしまう。
sen.e: After this one year and four months long invasion ended in failure with Yoshitaka losing his adopted son Harumochi OUCHI, Yoshitaka completely lost his political ambition.
After this one year and four month long invasion ended in failure with Yoshitaka losing his adopted son Harumochi OUCHI, Yoshitaka completely lost his political ambition.
After this one year and four month long invasion ended in failure with Yoshitaka losing his adopted son Harumochi OUCHI, Yoshitaka completely lost his political ambition.

sen.j: この戦いは大内氏衰退の一因となった一方、尼子氏は晴久のもとで勢力を回復させ、最盛期を創出する。
sen.e: This battle became a factor in the decline of the Ouchi clan; the Amago clan, on the other hand, regained its power under Haruhisa and entered the golden age.
This battle became a factor in the decline of the Ouchi clan; the Amago clan, on the other hand, regained its power under Haruhisa and entered a golden age.
This battle became a factor in the decline of the Ouchi clan; the Amago clan, on the other hand, regained its power under Haruhisa and entered a golden age.

sen.j: また、大内氏の滅亡後には石見国を巡って毛利氏と尼子氏が熾烈な争いを続けることとなった。
sen.e: After the fall of the Ouchi clan, the Mori clan continued to have a devastating conflict with the Amago clan over the Iwami Province.
After the fall of the Ouchi clan, the Mori clan continued to have a devastating conflict with the Amago clan over Iwami Province.
After the fall of the Ouchi clan, the Mori clan continued to have a devastating conflict with the Amago clan over Iwami Province.

sen.j: 大内氏が滅亡した後の永禄5年（1562年）、元就は息子の吉川元春・小早川隆景以下2万の軍勢で出雲国へ侵攻した。
sen.e: After the fall of the Ouchi clan in 1562, Motonari invaded the Izumo Province with an army of 20,000 men, including his son Motoharu KIKKAWA and Takakage KOBAYAKAWA.
After the fall of the Ouchi clan in 1562, Motonari invaded Izumo Province with an army of 20,000 men, including his son Motoharu KIKKAWA and Takakage KOBAYAKAWA.
After the fall of the Ouchi clan in 1562, Motonari invaded Izumo Province with an army of 20,000 men, including his son Motoharu KIKKAWA and Takakage KOBAYAKAWA.

sen.j: 尼子側は前年に晴久が亡くなっており、息子の尼子義久が跡を継いでいた。
sen.e: For the Amago's side, Haruhisa died in the previous year, and his son Yoshihisa AMAGO succeeded him.
On the Amago side Haruhisa died in the previous year and was succeeded by his son Yoshihisa AMAGO.
On the Amago side Haruhisa died in the previous year and was succeeded by his son Yoshihisa AMAGO.

sen.j: まず毛利側は「尼子十旗」と呼ばれる支城の一つ、白鹿城を攻めた。
sen.e: First of all, the Mori's side attacked the Shiraga-jo Castle, one of "Amago Jikki" (ten subsidiary castles to protect the Amago's main castle, Gassan Toda-jo Castle).
First, the Mori forces attacked Shiraga-jo Castle, one of the "Amago Jikki" (ten subsidiary castles to protect the main Amago castle, Gassan Toda-jo Castle).
First, the Mori forces attacked Shiraga-jo Castle, one of the "Amago Jikki" (ten subsidiary castles to protect the main Amago castle, Gassan Toda-jo Castle).

sen.j: 白鹿城を守るのは松田満久と牛尾久清の2,000の軍勢だった。
sen.e: The Shiraga-jo Castle was protected by the army of 2,000 men under the command of Mitsuhisa MATSUDA and Hisakiyo USHIO.
Shiraga-jo Castle was protected by an army of 2,000 men under the command of Mitsuhisa MATSUDA and Hisakiyo USHIO.
Shiraga-jo Castle was protected by an army of 2,000 men under the command of Mitsuhisa MATSUDA and Hisakiyo USHIO.

sen.j: 白鹿城は月山富田城の日本海側の玄関口ともいうべき役割の城である。
sen.e: The Shiraga-jo Castle functioned as a gateway to the Japan Sea's side of the Gassan Toda-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Shiraga-jo Castle functioned as a gateway to the Japan Sea side of the Gassan Toda-jo Castle.
Shiraga-jo Castle functioned as a gateway to the Japan Sea side of the Gassan Toda-jo Castle.

sen.j: ここが落ちると尼子側は船で日本海から兵糧を運び込めず、月山富田城が孤立することに毛利側は着目したのである。
sen.e: The Mori's side noticed that if this castle surrendered, the Amago's side could not carry the supply of provisions from the Japan Sea by boats, and the Gassan Toda-jo Castle would be helpless.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Mori forces noticed that if this castle surrendered, the Amago forces could not transport the supply of provisions from the Japan Sea by boat, and Gassan Toda-jo Castle would be helpless.
The Mori forces noticed that if this castle surrendered, the Amago forces could not transport the supply of provisions from the Japan Sea by boat, and Gassan Toda-jo Castle would be helpless.

sen.j: 戦いの最中、1563年毛利隆元が急死した。
sen.e: During the battle, Takamoto MORI died suddenly in 1563.
During the battle, Takamoto MORI died suddenly in 1563.
During the battle, Takamoto MORI died suddenly in 1563.

sen.j: 元就は悲しみを顔に出さず「隆元への追善は尼子氏の撃滅のほかになし」と将兵を諭したので、全軍の士気は奮い立った。
sen.e: Motonari tried to conceal his grief and talked to his soldiers, saying, "The only thing for the repose of Takamoto's soul is to destroy the Amago clan," so the morale of the whole army soared.
Motonari tried to conceal his grief and talked to his soldiers, saying, "The only thing for the repose of Takamoto's soul is to destroy the Amago clan," and the morale of the whole army soared.
Motonari tried to conceal his grief and talked to his soldiers, saying, "The only thing for the repose of Takamoto's soul is to destroy the Amago clan," and the morale of the whole army soared.

sen.j: 元就は石見銀山の鉱夫を使って、白鹿城の井戸を制圧して、白鹿城の水を絶つために、坑道を掘らせた。
sen.e: Motonari employed coalminer workers to make a tunnel for the purpose of capturing a water well of the Shiraga-jo Castle and cutting off the water supply.
Motonari employed coalminers to make a tunnel for the purpose of capturing a water well of Shiraga-jo Castle and cutting off the water supply.
Motonari employed coalminers of Iwami silver mine to make a tunnel for the purpose of capturing a water well of Shiraga-jo Castle and cutting off the water supply.

sen.j: 尼子側は義久の弟である尼子倫久ら10,000の軍を白鹿城の救援に送ったものの功を奏さず、10月に城は陥落した。
sen.e: The Amago's side sent an army of 10,000 men including Yoshihisa's brother Tomohisa AMAGO to the relief of the Shiraga-jo Castle; however, it was not successful, and that made the castle fall in October.
The Amago side sent an army of 10,000 men including Yoshihisa's brother Tomohisa AMAGO to the relief of Shiraga-jo Castle; however it was not successful and the castle fell in October.
The Amago side sent an army of 10,000 men including Yoshihisa's brother Tomohisa AMAGO to the relief of Shiraga-jo Castle; however it was not successful and the castle fell in October.

sen.j: 11月になると毛利軍は月山富田城の近くに陣を敷き、持久戦に持ち込んだ。
sen.e: In November, the Mori army occupied a position near the Gassan Toda-jo Castle to engage in a war of attrition.
In November, the Mori army occupied a position near Gassan Toda-jo Castle to engage in a war of attrition.
In November, the Mori army occupied a position near Gassan Toda-jo Castle to engage in a war of attrition.

tit.j: 第二次月山富田城の戦い
tit.e: The Second Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle
The Second Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle
The Second Battle of Gassan Toda-jo Castle

sen.j: 白鹿城を制圧した毛利元就は、尼子氏の拠点を次々と制圧し、永禄8年（1565年）、月山富田城を包囲し、輸送路を断ち切り、兵糧攻めを行った。
sen.e: After the conquest of the Shiraga-jo Castle, Motonari MORI gained control of the Amago clan's military bases one after another; in 1565, they besieged the Gassan Toda-jo Castle and cut off the supply route to starve out the enemy.

After the conquest of Shiraga-jo Castle, Motonari MORI gained control of the Amago clan's military bases one by one; in 1565, his forces besieged Gassan Toda-jo Castle and cut off the supply route so as to starve the enemy.

After the conquest of Shiraga-jo Castle, Motonari MORI gained control of the Amago clan's military bases one by one; in 1565, his forces besieged Gassan Toda-jo Castle and cut off the supply route so as to starve the enemy.

sen.j: 同年4月、毛利軍は3方向から月山富田城を攻撃したが、負け戦となり、撤退した。
sen.e: In April the same year, the Mori army attacked the Gassan Toda-jo Castle from three sides, but was defeated, and finally withdrew.
In April the same year, the Mori army attacked Gassan Toda-jo Castle from three sides, but was defeated, and finally withdrew.
In April the same year, the Mori army attacked Gassan Toda-jo Castle from three sides, but was defeated, and finally withdrew.

sen.j: 同年9月、再び毛利軍は月山富田城を包囲し、再び持久戦に持ち込んだ。
sen.e: In September the same year, the Mori army besieged the Gassan Toda-jo Castle again, and engaged in a war of attrition.
In September the Mori army besieged Gassan Toda-jo Castle oncemore, and engaged in a war of attrition.
In September the Mori army besieged Gassan Toda-jo Castle once more, and engaged in a war of attrition.

sen.j: 籠城戦は翌年まで続いた。
sen.e: The siege lasted until next year.
The siege lasted until the following year.
The siege lasted until the following year.

sen.j: はじめ、毛利側は城兵の降伏を一切認めなかった。
sen.e: The Mori's side did not accept an offer of surrender from castle defenders at first.
The Mori forces did not accept an offer of surrender from castle defenders at first.
The Mori forces did not accept an offer of surrender from castle defenders at first.

sen.j: こうすることで、孤立した城内に多くの兵がこもることになり、補給のない中で城の兵糧が底をつくのを待つ作戦であった。
sen.e: It was contemplated that many soldiers would be holed up in the isolated castle, and their provisions would run out without any supply.
It was envisaged that many soldiers would be holed up in the isolated castle, and their provisions would run out without fresh supplies.
It was envisaged that many soldiers would be holed up in the isolated castle, and their provisions would run out without fresh supplies.

sen.j: そして兵糧が底をつき始めたところで降伏を認めると、尼子方の籠城兵が数十人ずつの一団となって投降するようになった。
sen.e: Seeing as their provisions ran out, the Mori's side accepted the offer of surrender; dozens of the besieged soldiers formed a group and surrendered.
Seeing their provisions begin to run out, the Mori side accepted the offer of surrender, and dozens of the besieged soldiers formed a group and surrendered.
Seeing their provisions begin to run out, the Mori side accepted the offer of surrender, and dozens of the besieged soldiers formed a group and surrendered.

sen.j: 一方の尼子側は宇山久兼が私財をなげうって購入した兵糧を密かに間道から月山富田城に運び入れつつ、奮闘を続けていた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Amago's side continued to battle; they secretly carried provisions Hisakane UYAMA had bought with his own money into the Gassan Toda-jo Castle from a side road.
Meanwhile, the Amago side continued the battle by secretly carrying provisions Hisakane UYAMA had bought with his own money into Gassan Toda-jo Castle from a side road.
Meanwhile, the Amago side continued the battle by secretly carrying provisions Hisakane UYAMA had bought with his own money into Gassan Toda-jo Castle from a side road.

sen.j: しかし、尼子義久が讒言を信じて宇山久兼を殺してしまうという一件があり、士気を沮喪していった。
sen.e: However, there was an incident that Yoshihisa AMAGO killed Hisakane UYAMA by believing a slander; the army's spririts were gradually weakened.
However, following an incident when Yoshihisa AMAGO killed Hisakane UYAMA after believing he had been slandered the army's spririts were gradually weakened.
However, following an incident when Yoshihisa AMAGO killed Hisakane UYAMA after believing he had been slandered the army's spirits were gradually weakened.

sen.j: 永禄9年(1566年)11月21日尼子氏は降伏。
sen.e: The Amago clan surrendered on January 12, 1567.
sen.cmt: 日付はグレゴリオ暦に訂正しました
sen.e: The Amago clan surrendered on January 12, 1567.
The Amago clan surrendered on January 11, 1567.

sen.j: 毛利側は尼子義久ら尼子一族の生命を保証し、義久らは安芸国に引き取られ幽閉された。
sen.e: The Mori's side guaranteed the lives of the Amago family including Yoshihisa AMAGO; Yoshihisa and others were taken away to the Aki Province and were placed under confinement.
The Mori side guaranteed the lives of the Amago family including Yoshihisa AMAGO, but Yoshihisa and others were taken away to Aki Province and were placed under confinement.
The Mori side guaranteed the lives of the Amago family including Yoshihisa AMAGO, but Yoshihisa and others were taken away to Aki Province and were placed under confinement.

sen.j: また、この戦いは、毛利輝元と吉川元長の初陣でもあった。
sen.e: In addition, this was a maiden battle for Terumoto MORI and Motonaga KIKKAWA.
In addition, this was the first battle in which Terumoto MORI and Motonaga KIKKAWA participated.
In addition, this was the first battle in which Terumoto MORI and Motonaga KIKKAWA participated.

sen.j: 尼子軍は降伏したが、それに不満を持った男がいた。
sen.e: There was a man who was discontented with the fact that the Amago army surrendered.
One man was discontented with the fact that the Amago army surrendered.
One man was discontented with the fact that the Amago army surrendered.

sen.j: 山中鹿介こと山中幸盛である。
sen.e: It was Yukimori YAMANAKA, known as Shikanosuke YAMANAKA.
It was Yukimori YAMANAKA, also known as Shikanosuke YAMANAKA.
It was Yukimori YAMANAKA, also known as Shikanosuke YAMANAKA.

sen.j: 幸盛は叔父である立原久綱らとともに尼子氏再興の活動に奔走する。
sen.e: Yukimori tried hard for the restoration of the Amago clan with his uncle Hisatsuna TACHIHARA.
Yukimori worked hard for the restoration of the Amago clan with his uncle Hisatsuna TACHIHARA.
Yukimori worked hard for the restoration of the Amago clan with his uncle Hisatsuna TACHIHARA.

sen.j: まず永禄11年（1568年）には、京都で僧籍にあった尼子国久の孫尼子勝久を還俗させて擁立。
sen.e: First of all, in 1568, they made Katsuhisa AMAGO, who was a grandson of Kunihisa AMAGO and a priest, quit the priesthood, and put him up as the head of the family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: First, in 1568, they made Katsuhisa AMAGO, a grandson of Kunihisa AMAGO and a priest, quit the priesthood, and installed him as the head of the family.
First, in 1568, they made Katsuhisa AMAGO, a grandson of Kunihisa AMAGO and a priest, quit the priesthood, and installed him as the head of the family.

sen.j: 尼子旧臣を募って但馬国に侵攻。
sen.e: Then, they recruited former retainers of the Amago clan and invaded the Tajima Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Then they recruited former retainers of the Amago clan and invaded Tajima Province.
Then they recruited former retainers of the Amago clan and invaded Tajima Province.

sen.j: 出雲国、因幡国を転戦し、尼子氏再興の志を秘めて山名氏の軍勢にも加わった。
sen.e: They took part in various battles held in the Izumo and the Inba Provinces, and even joined in the army of the Yamana clan with their aim to restore the Amago clan burning in their bosoms.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: They took part in various battles held in Izumo and Inba Province, and even joined the army of the Yamana clan with the aim of restoring the Amago clan firmly in mind.
sen.cmt: Grammar. "Burning in their bosoms" doesn't sound an objective phrase.
sen.e: They took part in various battles held in Izumo and Inaba Province, and even joined the army of the Yamana clan with the aim of restoring the Amago clan firmly in mind.

sen.j: 山名氏に謀叛して鳥取城に篭った武田高信を討つなどの軍功を立てている。
sen.e: Then, they performed a valiant service in such a way that they defeated Takanobu TAKEDA, who rebelled against the Yamana clan and holed up in the Tottori-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: They excelled militarily and defeated Takanobu TAKEDA, who rebelled against the Yamana clan and became holed up in Tottori-jo Castle.
They excelled militarily and defeated Takanobu TAKEDA, who rebelled against the Yamana clan and became holed up in Tottori-jo Castle.

sen.j: 山名氏を離れた後、尼子勝久らは出雲国の殆どを奪還に成功、一時的に尼子氏再興の足掛かりを築いた。
sen.e: After leaving the Yamana clan, Katsuhisa Amago and his party succeeded to recover most of the occupied territory in the Izumo Province; they temporarily gained a foothold toward the restoration of the Amago clan.

After leaving the Yamana clan, Katsuhisa Amago and his party succeeded in recovering most of the occupied territory in Izumo Province, and they temporarily gained a foothold toward the restoration of the Amago clan.

After leaving the Yamana clan, Katsuhisa Amago and his party succeeded in recovering most of the occupied territory in Izumo Province, and they temporarily gained a foothold toward the restoration of the Amago clan.

sen.j: 旗揚げの翌年（1569年）には、毛利方の天野隆重が守る月山富田城を攻め、出雲国からの毛利氏排除を試みた。
sen.e: After the levy of troops in 1569, they attacked the Gassan Toda-jo Castle protected by Takashige AMANO on the Mori's side and attempted to drive the Mori clan out of the Izumo Province.
After the levy of troops in 1569, they attacked Gassan Toda-jo Castle which was protected by Takashige AMANO on Mori's side and attempted to drive the Mori clan out of Izumo Province.
After the levy of troops in 1569, they attacked Gassan Toda-jo Castle which was protected by Takashige AMANO on Mori's side and attempted to drive the Mori clan out of Izumo Province.

sen.j: しかし、月山富田城の堅固さに阻まれ、断念。
sen.e: However, the Gassan Toda-jo Castle was so strongly fortified that they abandoned their attempt.
However, Gassan Toda-jo Castle was so strongly fortified that they abandoned their attempt.
However, Gassan Toda-jo Castle was so strongly fortified that they abandoned their attempt.

sen.j: しかも元亀2年（1571年）には、布部山の戦いに敗れた幸盛が、吉川元春に捕らえられている。
sen.e: Moreover, Yukimori, who had been defeated in the Battle of Fubeyama, was captured by Motoharu KIKKAWA in 1571.
Moreover, Yukimori, who had been defeated in the Battle of Fubeyama, was captured by Motoharu KIKKAWA in 1571.
Moreover, Yukimori, who had been defeated in the Battle of Fubeyama, was captured by Motoharu KIKKAWA in 1571.

sen.j: その後、身柄を拘束された幸盛は、赤痢を装って厠に入り浸り、その隙に厠から糞にまみれながらも脱走したといわれている。
sen.e: Then, Yukimori, who had been detained, pretended to contract dysentery and remained in the lavatory; seizing an opportunity, he reportedly escaped from the lavatory, smeared with feces.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, Yukimori, who had been detained, pretended to contract dysentery and remained in the lavatory; seizing an opportunity, he reportedly escaped through the lavatory smeared with feces.
However, Yukimori, who had been detained, pretended to contract dysentery and remained in the lavatory; seizing an opportunity, he reportedly escaped through the lavatory smeared with feces.

sen.j: 勝久とともに再び京都に逃れて織田信長を頼った。
sen.e: He fled to Kyoto again with Katsuhisa to ask Nobunaga ODA for help.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He fled to Kyoto again with Katsuhisa to ask Nobunaga ODA for help.
He fled to Kyoto again with Katsuhisa to ask Nobunaga ODA for help.

sen.j: 天正5年（1577年）、織田軍の中国平定戦略を遂行すべく豊臣秀吉が播磨国姫路城に進出すると、幸盛たちは姫路城の更に西方の上月城に入城。
sen.e: In 1577, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI advanced to the Himeji-jo Castle in the Harima Province to carry out the Oda army's strategy for subjugating the Chugoku district, Yukimori and his party entered the Kozuki-jo Castle located to the west of the Himeji-jo Castle.

In 1577, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI advanced to Himeji-jo Castle in Harima Province to carry out the Oda army's strategy for subjugating the Chugoku district, Yukimori and his party entered Kozuki-jo Castle located to the west of Himeji-jo Castle.

In 1577, when Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI advanced to Himeji-jo Castle in Harima Province to carry out the Oda army's strategy for subjugating the Chugoku district, Yukimori and his party entered Kozuki-jo Castle located to the west of Himeji-jo Castle.

sen.j: 対毛利戦線の最前線で身命を賭し、尼子氏再興を目指した。
sen.e: They fought in the front line of the battle against the Mori clan without regard for their lives in the hope of restoring the Amago clan.
They fought in the front line of the battle against the Mori clan without regard for their lives in the hope of restoring the Amago clan.
They fought in the front line of the battle against the Mori clan without regard for their lives in the hope of restoring the Amago clan.

sen.j: ところが、播磨国東部で別所長治が造反。
sen.e: However, Nagaharu BESSHO raised in rebellion in the eastern part of the Harima Province.
However, Nagaharu BESSHO raised a rebellion in the eastern part of Harima Province.
However, Nagaharu BESSHO raised a rebellion in the eastern part of Harima Province.

sen.j: さらに播磨国内の各地へも飛び火したため、秀吉は別所氏の三木城への攻撃優先を強いられてしまう（三木合戦）。
sen.e: As this rebellion had repercussions in various regions in the Harima Province, Hideyoshi had to attack the Miki-jo Castle of the Bessho clan before everything else (the Battle of Miki).

As this rebellion had repercussions in various regions in Harima Province, Hideyoshi had to attack Miki-jo Castle occupied by the Bessho clan before he could turn his attention to anything else (the Battle of Miki).

As this rebellion had repercussions in various regions in Harima Province, Hideyoshi had to attack Miki-jo Castle occupied by the Bessho clan before he could turn his attention to anything else (the Battle of Miki).

sen.j: 頼みとする秀吉の後援を喪失したため、毛利の大軍に攻囲された上月城の尼子軍は孤立無援。
sen.e: The Amago army in the Kozuki-jo Castle, which had been besieged by the massive force of the Mori clan, became isolated and helpless because they lost their remiaining hope of Hideyoshi's support.
The Amago army in Kozuki-jo Castle, which had been besieged by the massive forces of the Mori clan, became isolated and helpless because they lost any remaining hope of Hideyoshi's support.
The Amago army in Kozuki-jo Castle, which had been besieged by the massive forces of the Mori clan, became isolated and helpless because they lost any remaining hope of Hideyoshi's support.

sen.j: 終には、勝久以下の尼子一門の自害を以って城兵を助命、開城降伏した（上月城の戦い）。
sen.e: In the end, the lives of castle defenders were spared in exchange for the suicide of the Amago family including Katsuhisa; the Kozuki-jo Castle surrendered (the Battle of Kozuki-jo Caslte).
In the end, the lives of castle defenders were spared in exchange for the suicide of the Amago family including Katsuhisa, and Kozuki-jo Castle surrendered (the Battle of Kozuki-jo Castle).
In the end, the lives of castle defenders were spared in exchange for the suicide of the Amago family including Katsuhisa, and Kozuki-jo Castle surrendered (the Battle of Kozuki-jo Castle).

sen.j: 幸盛は再び捕虜となるが、前回の脱走劇の印象が根強かったために、護送中に殺害されてしまった。
sen.e: Yukimori was captured again; however, his dramatic escape was so firmly entrenched in the enemy's mind that he was killed while being escorted to prison.
Yukimori was captured again; however, his dramatic escape was so firmly entrenched in the enemy's mind that he was killed while being escorted to prison.
Yukimori was captured again; however, his dramatic escape was so firmly entrenched in the enemy's mind that he was killed while being escorted to prison.

sen.j: 毛利氏を煩わせ続けた幸盛の死によって、尼子再興軍も終焉することとなった。
sen.e: The death of Yukimori who had continuously bothered the Mori clan brought an end to the army for restoration of the Amago clan.
The death of Yukimori, who had continuously bothered the Mori clan, brought an end to the armed movement for the restoration of the Amago clan.
The death of Yukimori, who had continuously bothered the Mori clan, brought an end to the armed movement for the restoration of the Amago clan.
